She has arranged to leave London on the 18th for Port Said which will be her headquarters for some time. The plans for her further journey are very vague and would be dependent on what opportunities offer themselves. She would certain ly visit Egypt and the Hejaz. She had introductions to the Governor of Jedda and Sir Andrew Ryan, our Representative there. She hoped to obtain facilities from them that would enable her to see something of the country. If it were feasible she wanted to make her way as opportunity offered from Jedda to Aden, thence l^y way of the Hadramaut coast, Oman and the Persian Gulf to Koweit and Basra, then travelling through Iraq, probably by the Nairn route, to Damascus and thence to Transjordania and Palestine. She realised that her proposed journey from Jedda to Koweit might present difficulties and that it would probably be quite impossible to make any part of the journey over land. She thought it might be possible to travel by stages along the coast by vessels trading between various ports. In that way she might see something of the people and the country. Her plans, however, would depend entirely on the advice and assistance she received at Jedda. She hoped that the introductions she held would serve to enlist the help of the authorities in the Hejaz for the furtherance of her plans but she would be guided entirely by the advice she received from them. She understood fully the risks she might run if she acted contrary to official advice. On one of her previous journeys she had had an actual experience of this and had been told ( I think she said it was by Sir Percy) that her action on this occasion might have caused the despatch of an expedition for -A herler rescue and that she was not worth it. ^ She does not propose to stay for any length of time in Iraq which she has Tisited before and she has signed the usual undertaking, of which a copy is attached. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. File notes appear at the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover, and terminates at the inside back cover; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 7-13; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and can be found in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: This file concerns a proposed and actual visits to the Persian Gulf by the writer Lady Dorothy Mills to countries in the Middle East in 1932 for the purpose of collecting suitable material for her literary work, with permission granted to her to travel to Muscat, Bahrain and Kuwait, but not the Trucial Coast (ff 7-11); and Lady Stokes, widow of Sir Wilfred Stokes, and Miss Hastings, daughter of Colonel Sir George Hastings, to Bahrain in 1937 (ff 12-14).Correspondents in this file include: Lieutenant-Colonel Trenchard Craven Fowle, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf at Bushire; Lieutenant-Colonel Percy Gordon Loch, Political Agent at Bahrain; and Sir Courtenay Latimer, the British Resident at Rajkot.
